questions.question: 1) Are there any vaccination goals and targets?
questions.q1: a. There are goals for future vaccine needs(e.g., over the next 3, 5 or 10 years)
questions.q2: b. There is more than specific, officially published and well-known national vaccination target to be researched by a specific date (e.g., measles elimination by end 2025).

questions.question: 2) Is there a national vaccination plan?
questions.q1: a. There is one (and only one) plan published by a WHO-type NITAG
questions.q2: b. Pipeline vaccines are continuously reviewed pre-licensure by NITAG.

questions.question: 3) Is there appropriate implementation of the NITAG plan?
questions.q1: a. There are clearly defined responsibilities and accountabilities for implementation of the NITAG plan with action in case of failure.
questions.q2: b. The NITAG plan is regularly supported by government-funded national information campaigns.

questions.question: 4) Is there a scientifically valid evaluation of implementation success?
questions.q1: a. There are up to date (less than every 2 years) validated studies on vaccine-uptake, completion and compliance at age 2 years, before shool entry, for adolescents and for those more than 65 years(some countires: more than 60 years).
questions.q2: b. There is scientifically sound and timely (less than 2 years) burden-of-diseases data by age group on all vaccine-preventable diseases including relevant pipelione vaccines.

questions.question: 1) Are there any vaccination goals and targets?
questions.q1: a. There are goals for future vaccine needs(e.g., over the next 3, 5 or 10 years)
questions.q2: b. There is more than specific, officially published and well-known national vaccination target to be researched by a specific date (e.g., measles elimination by end 2025).

questions.question: 2) Is there a national vaccination plan?
questions.q1: a. There is one (and only one) plan published by a WHO-type NITAG
questions.q2: b. Pipeline vaccines are continuously reviewed pre-licensure by NITAG.

questions.question: 3) Is there appropriate implementation of the NITAG plan?
questions.q1: a. There are clearly defined responsibilities and accountabilities for implementation of the NITAG plan with action in case of failure.
questions.q2: b. The NITAG plan is regularly supported by government-funded national information campaigns.

questions.q1: a. There are goals for future vaccine needs(e.g., over the next 3, 5 or 10 years)
questions.q2: b. There is more than specific, officially published and well-known national vaccination target to be researched by a specific date (e.g., measles elimination by end 2025).

questions.question: 2) Is there a national vaccination plan?
questions.q1: a. There is one (and only one) plan published by a WHO-type NITAG
questions.q2: b. Pipeline vaccines are continuously reviewed pre-licensure by NITAG.

questions.question: 3) Is there appropriate implementation of the NITAG plan?
questions.q1: a. There are clearly defined responsibilities and accountabilities for implementation of the NITAG plan with action in case of failure.
questions.q2: b. The NITAG plan is regularly supported by government-funded national information campaigns.

questions.question: 4) Is there a scientifically valid evaluation of implementation success?

questions.question: 2) Is there a national vaccination plan?
questions.q1: a. There is one (and only one) plan published by a WHO-type NITAG
questions.q2: b. Pipeline vaccines are continuously reviewed pre-licensure by NITAG.

questions.question: 3) Is there appropriate implementation of the NITAG plan?
questions.q1: a. There are clearly defined responsibilities and accountabilities for implementation of the NITAG plan with action in case of failure.
questions.q2: b. The NITAG plan is regularly supported by government-funded national information campaigns.

questions.question: 4) Is there a scientifically valid evaluation of implementation success?
questions.q1: a. There are up to date (less than every 2 years) validated studies on vaccine-uptake, completion and compliance at age 2 years, before shool entry, for adolescents and for those more than 65 years(some countires: more than 60 years).
questions.q2: b. There is scientifically sound and timely (less than 2 years) burden-of-diseases data by age group on all vaccine-preventable diseases including relevant pipelione vaccines.

questions.q2: b. There is scientifically sound and timely (less than 2 years) burden-of-diseases data by age group on all vaccine-preventable diseases including relevant pipelione vaccines.

questions.question: 1) Are there any vaccination goals and targets?
questions.q1: a. There are goals for future vaccine needs(e.g., over the next 3, 5 or 10 years)
questions.q2: b. There is more than specific, officially published and well-known national vaccination target to be researched by a specific date (e.g., measles elimination by end 2025).

questions.question: 2) Is there a national vaccination plan?
questions.q1: a. There is one (and only one) plan published by a WHO-type NITAG
questions.q2: b. Pipeline vaccines are continuously reviewed pre-licensure by NITAG.

questions.question: 3) Is there appropriate implementation of the NITAG plan?
questions.q1: a. There are clearly defined responsibilities and accountabilities for implementation of the NITAG plan with action in case of failure.
questions.q2: b. The NITAG plan is regularly supported by government-funded national information campaigns.
